thread.title: Mater Dei beats Harvard again to capture North-South Challenge
thread.title_full: Mater Dei beats Harvard again to capture North-South Challenge

author: DAN ALBANO
title: Mater Dei beats Harvard again to capture North-South Challenge
text:
Mater Dei beats Harvard again to capture North-South Challenge October 24, 2015 8:41 PM BY DAN ALBANO OCVARSITY.COM 
Mater Dei’s boys water polo team is now streaking in a positive direction against rival Harvard-Westlake of Studio City, and at just the right time. 
Lefty Luke Wyatt skipped in a hard, side-armed shot for the only goal of the fourth period and the Monarchs stopped four power-play chances in the final seven minutes to edge the Wolverines, 11-10, in the finals of the North-South Challenge in Atherton on Saturday night. 
Mater Dei (20-1) beat Harvard-Westlake (18-2) by the same score Oct. 14 to snap a six-game losing streak against the Wolverines, including the past two Division 1 finals. 
The Monarchs moved to No. 1 in the Division 1 rankings with the victory and defended that position Saturday. The score was tied seven times, including at 10 entering the fourth period. 
Wyatt scored on Mater Dei’s first possession of the fourth and moments after the Monarchs fended off the first of four power-play chances by the Wolverines in the final period. 
Wyatt and center Sean Duncan each finished with four goals. Duncan also netted the tying goal with 14 seconds left in the third period. The Princeton commit made a steal, drew an exclusion and scored on a power-play to tie the score, 10-10. 
The Monarchs finished 6 for 9 on the man-advantage while Harvard-Westlake went 2 for 8. Mater Dei goalie Nolan Strout recorded eight saves. 
In the third-place: 
No. 5 Huntington Beach 15, Sacred Heart Prep 6: Curtis Jarvis scored four goals and Patrick Saunders made 14 saves to lead the Oilers (19-6). 
In the seventh-place game: 
Miramonte 11, No. 4 Dana Hills 10: Jack McLaughlin scored with 1:18 left in the fourth to draw the Dolphins (17-4) within one but they didn’t score again.
